how does ES5 distinguish between illegal programs that work in a well-defined way and legal programs that work in a well-defined way?
Suppose one writes "\/"
I see that / doesn't match SingleEscapeCharacter
and I see that the above is therefore equivant with "/"
but what cues should I look for to know it is conforming?
is stuff that "works" always conforming in ES5?
clearly, I can't use JSLint, since it encodes Crockford's opinion--not the spec
isn't anything that matches the grammar conforming?
and vice-versa?
Working in practice is not a guarantee of being conforming, at least, since browsers aren't always 100% by the spec
Hixie: dunno
2 Conformance just talks about conforming implementations
Hixie: isn't the whole semicolon insertion mechanism based on first hitting an error in the grammar and then magically correcting it?
hsivonen: beats me
haha, http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Member/w3c-ac-members/2011JanMar/0006.html

just as we're moving on from html5...

“HTML5“, OTOH … !
hsivonen: Semicolon insertion only works once, if there's still an error after insertion it's an invalid program
Dashiva: "invalid program" is not a term defined by ES5
Well, it produces a syntax error

'scuse me all. Quick Q about forms. Trying to understand if entering the letter "K" into input type=number should be an error. It's not out of range for a number eg min=1 max=10 but seems to me it should be a type mismatch. However, spec says only email, url can have type mismatch. http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/Overview.html#suffering-from-a-type-mismatch or am i reading it wrong?
MikeSmith: onclick="(" validates in v.nu
brucel, the rule specifically talks about controls which allow arbitrary user input, which <input number> does not
zcorpan: well that's bad… guess we'll have to fix it
all it's doing now is handing it straight off to the rhino compiler
brucel, constrained input for <input type=number> could be interpreted as "just throw everything away that's not a number" I guess
MikeSmith: got an example where it gives an error?
which is what various OS controls do as well
zcorpan: yeah, that one
if you try it at http://www.w3.org/html/check
ah
I guess hsivonen didn't redeploy that code at validator.nu yet
thought he had on Friday
MikeSmith: ooops. sorry.
no biggie
brucel: the browser will never set the value to "K" even if it displays it in the contrcol
control
Hixie, but should it be a type mismatch?
MikeSmith: cool
brucel: should what be a type mismatch?
brucel: say you started with <input type=number value=0> and typed K in it. The value is still going to be "0", which is a number -- not a type mismatch.
the display might say "K" but what is validated is the value, not the display.
well, having a type mismatch is defined as "Suffering from a type mismatch: When a control that allows arbitrary user input has a value that is not in the correct syntax (E-mail, URL)."
MikeSmith: next up is checking <script> if the type is javascript? :)
lord please no
does the spec require that now?
it didn't last time I checked
brucel: right, so?
brucel: type=number doesn't allow arbitrary user input
MikeSmith: It would be quite inconsistent if it didn't
(so it probably should in any case)
well, that would be in line with the platform itself
yeah
true
could warn about it at least
it should check it against python if the type is python, too :-)
and against 80286 assembler if the type is 80286 assembler :-)
simple warning for that case
(but the validator isn't required to support any languages)
"warning: don't do that"
(iirc)
brucel, what is somewhat difficult, but important here, is that the new form controls have several values
Hixie: you made it require checking for event-handler attributes
MikeSmith: appears the spec doesn't require <script> to compile
Hixie anneck: so there can never be a type mismatch for type=number, so to check that the user has entered something numeric, yoiu have to use some regex with pattern attrib, right?
brucel, a "UI value" (what the user sees), an "actual value" (what the user agent has computed), and maybe things such as a "default value"
zcorpan: w00t
MikeSmith: yeah, well, there's no way to change the language for event handler attributes
MikeSmith: so it's not open-ended
brucel, e.g. for URL the user might see "www.example.org" which is not valid, but the "actual value" might be "http://www.example.org" which is
MikeSmith: <script> is open-ended
brucel, for Number the idea is that you never change it to a non-number, only a number that is not within the range
Hixie: So if you specify <script type="text/javascript"> the spec doesn't care if there is a SyntaxError? Why the difference?
brucel, so if the UI allowed entering K (and displaying it back) (the UI value), the "actual value" would still be a number
holy cow, i really didn't require that the <script>'s contents be valid
annevk so if I have <input type=number> what actually is the number?
that's totally bogus
files a bug
brucel: ""
Hixie: i already did
ah
well then
heh
dupes all around!
submits as well
brucel, well okay, no value is also an option
brucel, another important thing is that the interaction between the UI value and actual value is up to the user agent, much like all UI decisions
hey
brucel, so entering "K" in the UI could mean erasing the value or could mean not changing the current value, or changing it to zero
i was wondering whether there are webkit branches that have some experimental websocket features, like the sony ericsson webcam-over-websocket demo
brucel, ideally though UI implementations are not that crazy and simply disallow that :)
entering "K" could mean setting the value to 1000! :-)

phrearch, #webkit might be a better channel
annevk: ok thanks
brucel, no
brucel, pattern="" does not even apply, why would you need it?
to prevent 'K' - regardless of meaning, I would assume
annevk want to check that user entered a number = numerics
brucel: the user can't enter anything but a number
brucel, that is all the user can do per the constraints of the specification (note that the UI value is never exposed to anyone but the user)
Would it be a bug in chrome if your element starts as <input type=number value=15 /> and if the user deletes the characters in the input the elem.value is still '15' and not '' ?
or would that conform to spec

annevk zcorpan OK. So I think I'm getting a soupcon of comprehension. So: the ability to type something non-numeric is a UA decision (it could require you to choose from a spinner, for example). What the user actually type has no relation to the contents of the field. But how to give sensible feedback to the user?
it could theoretically conform to the spec, but it sounds like a bug in the UI SlexAxton
kk, will file.
brucel, the UA should give sensible feedback
brucel, if the UA has not implemented the control well, there are two options
brucel: it's up to the UA to worry about all this
brucel: that's the whole point of semantic markup -- you say what you want, and the browser takes care of it
brucel, a) get the UA fixed; b) wait for the UA to implement something XBL-like and fix it yourself
gotcha. thanks annvk and hixie
hsivonen: you looking at section 16 of the EcmaScript spec?

it just says what should be reported as errors
and "All errors that are not early errors are runtime errors."
i guess that's one way to define it

so apparently browsers don't implement a11y by mapping elements to roles and then roles to native aapis
they just map elements to native aapis except if roles are present in which case they let the roles override the default mapping

Hixie: WebKit has a role concept internally
Hixie: some directly correspond to ARIA roles, others do not
in general, we assign a role to every element, whether or not it has a role attribute
this is because A11Y APIs expect their own concept of role as one of the pieces of data about a UI element
we map our internal ARIA-like roles to the respective A11Y API's role
Hixie: so at least as to WebKit, I don't think your description of how browsers do things is totally accurate

TabAtkins: about image(), if I want to use webp today (cause it offers better compression) I'd like to do it without having an extra HTTP request
cause with an extra HTTP request, it kinds of the defeat the purpose of using a lighter image format
also, if the feature was already implemented, it would greatly simplify using SVG files on the web right now
Rik`: I agree that dealing with the format stuff is a useful feature.  I don't know if it's worth complicating up the syntax that much.
Like, you'll get "background-image: image( "foo.webp" "image/webp", "foo.svg" "image/svg+xml", blue );"
Plus maybe that weird resolution-handling stuff.
why image/webp and not only webp ?
Argh, I don't like the resolution stuff either.  Again, useful functionality, but I don't think it fits in the image() function.
I assumed it would be by mimetype?
font-face doesn't use mimetype
Yeah, it defines a small list of types.
but I could live with mimetype

Actually... going with that, and inverting the functionality (only download the resource is the type isn't specified, or if it is specified and it's something you think can render) might be more useful.
That way new formats like webp automatically work as expected - they get ignored until they're supported.
http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2295.txt never implemented I think :/
Transparent Content Negotiation in HTTP
was proposing an Alternates:  header
giving all the type of resources available
